Alondra Márquez

Welcome to my personal website!


About Me


I’m an undergraduate student in the Genomic Sciences program at UNAM, currently in my fourth semester. My academic training combines molecular biology with computational approaches to better understand complex biological systems.


My primary research interests center on plant–microbe interactions and their implications for food security in the context of climate change. I am particularly interested in understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate host–pathogen and host–symbiont relationships, integrating perspectives from evolutionary genomics, transcriptional regulation, and functional molecular biology.


I am currently part of a research group at the Institute of Biotechnology (UNAM), where I am gaining experience in the study of oxygen perception, hypoxia signaling, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) dynamics during plant–microbe interactions. Through this work, I am developing both experimental and computational skills while contributing to ongoing projects.

Beyond the Lab


Outside of research and university, I really enjoy reading. I’m especially drawn to science fiction and books that question society, power, and the problems we face as a world.


I also love running, especially long distances. For me, there is something meaningful about sustained effort and pushing through when it gets difficult, realizing that you are still capable of going further. One of my goals is to run a marathon, and in the future my mom and I hope to complete a 100 km ultramarathon together.

title: Current Projects
text:
The Response to Hypoxic Conditions in Plants: From an Evolutionary Approach to New Strategies in Single Cells that Define the Global Response Mechanism During Biotic, Abiotic, and Symbiotic Stress in Plants.

status: 2024-present
This project investigates how plants sense and respond to low oxygen (hypoxic) conditions during development and stress. Although hypoxia is often associated with flooding, plants naturally generate low-oxygen niches in tissues such as root meristems and symbiotic nodules. The research explores how oxygen perception—primarily through ERF-VII transcription factors and Plant Cysteine Oxidases (PCOs)—regulates developmental programs, stress responses, and plant–microbe interactions.

ERF-VII / PCO Coevolution Across the Plant Kingdom

status: 2025-present
This project aims to investigate the evolutionary relationship between ERF-VII transcription factors and Plant Cysteine Oxidases (PCOs), two key components of the plant oxygen-sensing pathway. The goal is to evaluate how these protein families have diversified and potentially coevolved across a broad range of photosynthetic organisms, from algae to flowering plants.

Phaseolus vulgaris Transcriptomic Database

status: 2025-present
Development of a web-based database integrating publicly available RNA-seq dataset from Phaseolus vulgaris under multiple experimental conditions. The platform aims to enable cross-study comparisons, differential expression exploration, and improved accessibility to transcriptomic data for functional genomics research.

TET8 and Extracellular Vesicle-Mediated Plant Immunity

status: 2026-present
Exploring the molecular role of TET8-associated extracellular vesicles in plant defense signaling and intercellular communication.

Fungal Adaptation: Stress Responses, Spore Survival, and Polar Growth Dynamics

status: 2026-present
This project aims to investigate how filamentous fungi sense and respond to environmental stress through MAPK and SrrA regulatory pathways. By comparing the model fungus Aspergillus nidulans with the halophilic species Aspergillus sydowii, the research explores how stress signaling networks regulate spore viability, oxidative and osmotic stress responses, and the establishment of polarized growth.
